body.p: High-end computers rule the gaming community! Extreme computing is more often than not distributed problem solving, but that doesn’t mean we all can’t own a kick-ass box. So the question becomes, “where to look?” We all want massive power in a desktop computer, but there’s something you may not have realized—money will be a brick wall when it pleases. As consumers we settle down and we focus. Should one get a Dell or possibly bite the bullet and go for an Alienware? After some extension data comparison, I can conclusively say that if you have about $7,000 you can get a keyboard-shattering Alienware ALX. For about 6 grand you can max out your Dell XPS 600 and still pack a good punch.

For those of us without an infinite pocketbook, I took the liberty of configuring two comparable machines. I went to Dell’s and Alienware’s websites and did my best to match two machines component by component. The two machines I chose were the Dell XPS 600 and the Alienware Area-51 7500. The following is that machine(NOTE):

ul.li: Pentium® D Processor 840 with Dual Core Technology (3.20GHz, 800FSB)
Dual 256MB Nvidia GeForce 7800 GTX with SLI Technology DIMMs | Comes with copy of Battefield 2
2GB Dual Channel DDR2 SDRAM at 667MHz - 2 DIMMs
80GB Serial ATA Hard Drive (10000RPM) | 74GB Serial ATA 10,000 RPM w/8MB Cache
Dual Drives: 16x DVD-ROM Drive + 16x DVD+/-RW w/ dbl layer write capable
Sound Blaster® X-Fi™ XtremeMusic (D), w/Dolby® Digital 5.1
Dell Only: 20 inch UltraSharp™ 2005FPW Widescreen Digital Flat Panel

body.p:
Dell XPS 600: $4,483.00 as configured
Alienware Area-51 7500: $4,266.00 as configured

The Alienware Area-51 7500 can be brought up to 4GB of RAM; the Second Harddisk Drive can be 1TB in space; the DVD-Burner can come with LightScribe Technology. The Dell can do none of those things, so the Area-51 was not configured with those options, but rather with the equivalent Dell components.

If you look closely you’ll see the Area-51 comes with Battlefield 2(a $50 value), and the XPS comes with a 20” Digital Flat Panel. To get such a monitor with your Area-51 you’ll need to add about $725 to the sticker price. Everyone will be happy to learn that both systems ship for free.

These machines aren’t the same, because the cases are different and the cooling systems are different. In this configuration I used standard cooling for the Area-51 to make it as close to the same machine as possible. As for me, I own an Alienware Area-51m and a Dell XPS Gen 2, and if I were to buy a solid gaming machine, for a good price, I’d get a Dell. If I wanted to get an amazingly powerful machine forcing me to sell my organs and all other possessions, I’d get an Alienware. The sticker price of the configured Dell XPS 600 is $4,483 and the sticker price of the Alienware Area-51 7500 is $4,266(w/o monitor).
